title: Fix hoisting examples
body:
Hoisting only happens to `var`. As kangax describes in [Why `typeof` is no longer “safe”](http://es-discourse.com/t/why-typeof-is-no-longer-safe/15/3).

Also, I wonder if we need the whole section, since you recommend to [avoid using `var` altogether](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/blob/b492/README.md#references).

BTW, this is a clean version of #303.

title: I have started translate to Turkish
Fix inconsistent use of direct assignment in place of Array#push
body: Style guide on Arrays specifies that one should avoid using direct assignment. Section on using Array#join in place of string concatenation now follows this recommendation.

title: "Prefix jQuery object variables with a $." Does this play well with AngularJS?
body:
I am glad to see the dollar sign prefix endorsed. This practice, which I think this is often referred to as Hungarian notation, has helped me easily identify jQuery-wrapped objects.

I believe that AngularJS employs a different meaning for a $ prefix, e.g., `$scope.$value`; `$ignore`; `$watch`.

Aside from code readability—because, unless you have `var $scope = $('.scope')`, it should be _mostly_ clear from context that `$scope` is not a jQuery-wrapped object—has prefixing jQuery object variables with a `$` been known to cause any issues on a page that employs both jQuery and AngularJS?

title: Suggestion to add switch
body:
Does it make sense to add switch
Because it's not clear add spaces before case or not

```
switch (expression) {
  case expression:
    statements
    break;
  default:
    statements
}
```

Or

```
switch (expression) {
case expression:
  statements
  break;
default:
  statements
}
```

title: Avoid using reserved word 'class' in Whitespace examples
Alphabetized Translation links
body: Hello. I think the translation links would be better organized alphabetically.

title: Fix minor punctuation errors in README
body:
(1) BEFORE: Never name a parameter `arguments`, this will take precedence over the `arguments` object.
AFTER: Never name a parameter `arguments`. This will take precedence over the `arguments` object.

(2) BEFORE: Variable declarations get hoisted to the top of their scope, their assignment does not.
AFTER:
Variable declarations get hoisted to the top of their scope, but their assignment does not.

(3) BEFORE: for multiline comments
AFTER: for multi-line comments

title: Reference people in TODO and FIXME
add `bad` comment to bad section of destructuring
adding a name to reference for TODO or FIXME
Fix a typo in selector
Invalid example in ES6 Modules section
body:
The [Modules](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#modules) section uses the "bad" example of:

``` javascript
export default { es6 } from './airbnbStyleGuide';
```

this is however not valid syntax. What I think you mean is:

``` javascript
export { es6 as default } from './airbnbStyleGuide';
```

title: Advice against side effect in default parameter
body: Side effect in default parameter should be discouraged as discussed in https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/285

title: Advise against default parameter with side-effect
body:
According to the ES6 spec, default arguments is evaluated `in the scope of the fresh activation (localEnv in ES5 10.4.3) for the current function`. This means every default argument behaves like a function that returns a value for the parameter and, thusly, can make side effect.

If side effect is done in default parameter, confusion and subtlety likely arise.  For a contrived example,

```
> var b = 1
> function count(a=b++) {
...  console.log(a)
... }
> count()
1
> count()
2
> count('hello world')
hello world
> count()
3
```

Arguments in JavaScript are evaluated eagerly, in applicative order, but  default parameter are (somewhat) evaluated by need, in normal order. It is quite possible for a ES6 newcomer, or even an experienced developer, accidentally forgets the evaluation strategy for default parameter. 

If a side effect does be desired, then a normal assignment statement is more explicit than default parameter. With more strokes to input, it also discourage side effect.

```
function count(a) {
   if (a === undefined) a = b++
}
```

After all, default parameter with side effect can be translated equivalently to ES5 `if ...` block. After all, it's just a matter of taste. So I think it is appropriate to place this in a style guide.

title: Change wording in Iterators and Generators
body:
I found the term "function constructors" to be confusing as the functions the section refers to are not constructors. I think "higher-order functions" or something similar would be more clear.

Thanks!

title: Rephrasing Array#push style guide
Rephrasing Array#push style guide
Parenthesis around single arguments in arrow functions
body:
> Always use parentheses around the arguments. Omitting the parentheses makes the functions less readable and only works for single arguments.
> 
> Why? These declarations read better with parentheses. They are also required when you have multiple parameters so this enforces consistency.
> 
> ``` js
>  // bad
>  [1, 2, 3].map(x => x * x);
> 
>  // good
>  [1, 2, 3].map((x) => x * x);
> ```

This stuck out to me as odd. It's an intentional part of the spec to make it more readable for simple cases.

Anyways, I'm interested in discussing this.

title: If you don't know array length
body:
This section:

> If you don't know array length use Array#push.

found [here](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript#arrays) is pretty weird. You should know the array length if you have access to the reference.

We just need to clean up this wording to say use Array#push rather than arr[n]

title: Added Adult Swim to In the Wild section

title: Initial ES6 style guide
body:
## A mostly reasonable approach to ES6

Don't want to read the updates in diff form? Read the ES6 style guide in full [here](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6).
### Introduction

Welcome to the future. This PR updates our style guide to reflect the current style for writing ES6 at Airbnb. As before, this is a living document and it'll change over time as we and the community learn. Of course, this isn't the "one true way to write ES6" and doesn't intend to be—just one _mostly_ reasonable approach.

We think having a style guide is important for readability of code and scalability of engineering teams. Our philosophy is that you shouldn't be able to tell who wrote a file based on the style of the code.

As always, please fork this guide and use it as a starting point for your own style guide, and if you hit on a problem or something you'd like to share, we welcome [Issues](/airbnb/javascript/issues/new) and [Pull Requests](/airbnb/javascript/compare)—we love having discussions about this stuff.
### What's New

We've updated existing sections to reflect ES6 best practices (i.e., `var` -> `const`) and added guides for the following language features:
- [Arrow Functions](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#arrow-functions)
- [Classes](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#constructors)
- [Object Shorthand](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-object-shorthand)
- [Object Concise](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-object-concise)
- [Object Computed Properties](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-computed-properties)
- [Template Strings](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-template-literals)
- [Destructuring](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#destructuring)
- [Default Parameters](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-default-parameters)
- [Rest](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-rest)
- [Array Spreads](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#es6-array-spreads)
- [Let and Const](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#references)
- [Iterators and Generators](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#iterators-and-generators)
- [Modules](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6#modules)
### ES5 Support

We'll continue to maintain the ES5 style guide at [`/es5/README.md`](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6/es5). We moved the ES5 style guide into its own folder because Airbnb is moving towards ES6, and since this public repo is the style guide we use internally, we'd like it to reflect our current best practices.  We'll also be adding additional style guides that we use internally, like our in-progress React+JSX style guide.
### Learn ES6

Some resources we've found helpful in learning ES6:
- [ECMAScript Language Specification Draft](https://people.mozilla.org/~jorendorff/es6-draft.html)
- [ES6 Features](https://github.com/lukehoban/es6features)
- [Exploring JS](http://exploringjs.com)
- [ES6 Compatibility Table](http://kangax.github.io/compat-table/es6/)
### Compiling ES6

If you'd like to use ES6 syntax in a reasonable set of current browsers, you'll have to transpile your code to ES5. We recommend both [traceur](https://github.com/google/traceur-compiler) and [babel](http://babeljs.io) as activley-maintained, standards-compliant ES6 compilers. We use Babel internally.
### FAQ

What happened to the old guide?

> It's still here! Have a look: [`/es5/README.md`](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6/es5)

Should I be writing ES6?

>  Up to you and your team! We're making the switch at Airbnb. Check out our ES5 style guide if you're not making the jump yet.

Why does JavaScript need a style guide?

> A great question, see: [#102](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/issues/102)
### Next Steps

The plan is to merge this after a week or so of gathering feedback from the community. Have a look and let us know your thoughts.

[Read the ES6 style guide](https://github.com/airbnb/javascript/tree/es6)

Special thanks go out to @iamnirav, @alvinsng, @hshoff, @justjake, and @spikebrehm for looking at a draft of this.

Fixes part of #247.
